<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
REAL ESTATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/15/rents-plummet-madison-ave-might-still-high-economic-recovery?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Madison Avenue Goes on Sale
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Retail vacancies" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNzk3L3JldGFpbF92YWNhbmNpZXMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Soon, you might be able to buy an entire Dolce & Gabbana store for less than one of its patterned dresses.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s a slight exaggeration, but here’s the point: Commercial real estate, particularly of the high-end variety, is getting crushed during the pandemic. Rents along NYC’s ritzy Madison Avenue are <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-15/madison-avenue-rent-plunges-with-manhattan-retail-taking-a-hit?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">down 17%</a> in Q3, according to brokerage Cushman & Wakefield. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What’s going on: </strong>Covid-19 brutalized urban retail corridors. First, cities emptied out when companies started working from home. At the same time, people started shopping online by the cartload (which puts more demand on warehouses, not actual store locations). Finally, the tourists so many of these luxury retailers depend on were forced to take staycations.  <strong style="color:#000"></strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">An extreme example: </strong></span><span>Swiss retailer Akris just bought three properties along Madison Ave. at about </span><span><em>80% below </em></span><span>peak sales prices in 2014 ($1,340/square foot average vs. $7,589), </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/madison-avenues-prime-retail-properties-sell-for-decade-low-price-11602586801?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writes the WSJ</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Now for an M. Night Shyamalan twist</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">They might appear in the dumps, but commercial rents are still <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/11/opinion/nyc-commercial-rent-reform.html?referringSource=articleShare&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>too </em>high</a> right now, and that’s crippling NYC and other cities’ abilities to rebound economically, argues Columbia University law professor Tim Wu in a NYT op-ed. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Wu writes that rents don’t reflect current market conditions. Landlords are incentivized to keep rents artificially high for a few reasons, including... </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Some landlords can afford to be patient and hold out for when demand returns.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Other landlords simply can’t lower rents based on agreements with lenders.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Lower rents can lead to depressed property values, the last thing a landlord wants.</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Inflated rents are bad for the economy because when businesses can’t afford to set up shop, high vacancy rates can suck the vitality out of a neighborhood. In Times Square in Q3, 29% of space was available. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>Wu proposes a few fixes, such as establishing minimum-rent terms and tweaking zoning laws, and says cities can use this crisis as an opportunity to come back better than ever.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PAYMENTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/15/stripe-acquire-nigerian-fintech-paystack?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The "Stripe of Africa" Is Being Acquired By...
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Paystack cofounders" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNzk4L3BheXN0YWNrX2NvZm91bmRlcnMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Paystack</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You’ll never guess: Stripe. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, payments processor Stripe announced <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/10/15/stripe-acquires-nigerias-paystack-for-200m-to-expand-into-the-african-continent/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">it’s acquiring</a> Nigerian fintech Paystack for a rumored $200+ million—a record-setting deal for both Stripe and Nigeria. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Similar to its new parent, Paystack offers software that facilitates digital transactions for 60,000+ business customers. TechCrunch previously dubbed it “the Stripe of Africa,” and Stripe led an $8 million round in Paystack in 2018.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong data-stringify-type="bold" style="color:#000">The similarities continue: </strong></span><span>Paystack was a 2016 grad of Silicon Valley’s esteemed Y Combinator accelerator, as was Stripe in 2010.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Stripe’s been looking abroad for a while </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In April, the company raised $600 million at a $36 billion valuation to help fund international expansion. In the last 18 months, it’s moved into 17 new countries. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Paystack acquisition shows Stripe is betting on emerging African markets, where e-commerce is growing faster than the global average. And among them, Nigeria is the strongest magnet for tech: Last year, Nigerian fintechs received a quarter of all VC funding that went to African startups.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=The+%24200+million+deal+would+be+Stripe%E2%80%99s+and+Nigeria%E2%80%99s+largest+to+date&url=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/15/stripe-acquire-nigerian-fintech-paystack&via=MorningBrew" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
EDUCATION
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/15/college-enrollment-especially-firstyear-students-continues-fall?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Empty Dorms Are the New Norm
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A National Student Clearinghouse report surveyed institutions representing 9.2 million students just to come to the same conclusion one could arrive at by scrolling through TikTok—<a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/michaeltnietzel/2020/10/15/college-enrollment-update-undergraduate-numbers-now-down-4-nationwide/#1ddd0eb6389d?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">way fewer</a> high-school grads enrolled in college this year. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Clearinghouse <a href="https://nscresearchcenter.org/stay-informed/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">report</a> found that overall undergraduate populations shrank by 4%, with over two-thirds of the decline coming from first-time college students. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Breaking it down: </strong>The biggest drop-off comes from community college enrollment, where freshman numbers are down 22.7%. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>That decline is surprising when you consider community college enrollment </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/college-enrollment-slid-this-fall-with-first-year-populations-down-16-11602734726?mod=hp_featst_pos3&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">often jumps</a></span><span> during a recession, as adults go back to school to acquire new skills and families look to save on tuition.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">One type of college weathering the storm?<strong style="color:#000"> </strong>Private, for-profit, four-year institutions. Enrollment is actually up 3.7% compared to the previous fall. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> With hopes of a V-shaped recovery fading, and family finances still under pressure, the ripple effects from the pandemic are rippling. “I fear that many of those students will never get back,” said Doug Shapiro, executive director of the National Student Clearinghouse.</p>

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/15/biden-victory-favors-cannabis-industry?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Green Is Pulling For Blue
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Big marijuana nugget" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNTAzL2JpZ193ZWVkX251Z2dldC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While every industry is preparing for any and all outcomes in the upcoming election, <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-stocks-cannabis-focus/cannabis-companies-betting-on-a-biden-win-ready-ipos-idUSKBN2702IO?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">U.S. weed companies</a> are banking on a Biden/Harris W. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">A joint effort: </strong>Sen. Kamala Harris, Biden’s VP pick, said during last week’s debate that the Biden administration would <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-cannabis-stocks/weed-stocks-surge-as-kamala-harris-vows-to-decriminalize-pot-in-debate-idUSKBN26T3IH?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">push for decriminalization</a> at the federal level if they win in November.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>And if the Senate also flips from red to blue, it will likely be more impactful for marijuana policy than whoever is sitting in the Oval Office. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Republican Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has repeatedly struck down legislation that would allow financial institutions more freedom to work with cannabis companies. If the Senate adopts a more chill stance on weed, it would pave the way for U.S.-based companies to <a href="https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/10/14/this-marijuana-stock-might-just-be-the-biggest-win/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">list their shares</a> on major stock exchanges.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>August cannabis sales were up 26% in California and 34% in Nevada compared to last year, according to BDS Analytics. A Biden victory could propel those numbers even...higher. </p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The race to Exascale computing is the space race of our century</strong>. What is <a href="https://www.hpe.com/us/en/insights/articles/argonne-national-laboratory-rick-stevens-talks-about-the-biggest-baddest-computer-2010.html?chatsrc=ot-en&jumpid=ba_d5w7vsbfj3_aid-520023674" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Exascale</a>? It’s a supercomputer performing a billion <em>billion</em> calculations per second. Imagine how researchers might use that kind of power to tackle everything from vaccine discovery to the climate crisis. HPE spoke with Rick Stevens, leader of Argonne National Lab’s Exascale Computing Initiative, about how these new supercomputers will change the world. <a href="https://www.hpe.com/us/en/insights/articles/argonne-national-laboratory-rick-stevens-talks-about-the-biggest-baddest-computer-2010.html?chatsrc=ot-en&jumpid=ba_d5w7vsbfj3_aid-520023674" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Read the Q&A</a>.</p>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nREAL ESTATE\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/15/rents-plummet-madison-ave-might-still-high-economic-recovery?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nMadison Avenue Goes on Sale\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Retail vacancies\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNzk3L3JldGFpbF92YWNhbmNpZXMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSoon, you might be able to buy an entire Dolce \u0026 Gabbana store for less than one of its patterned dresses.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s a slight exaggeration, but here’s the point: Commercial real estate, particularly of the high-end variety, is getting crushed during the pandemic. Rents along NYC’s ritzy Madison Avenue are \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-15/madison-avenue-rent-plunges-with-manhattan-retail-taking-a-hit?srnd=premium\u0026sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edown 17%\u003c/a\u003e in Q3, according to brokerage Cushman \u0026 Wakefield. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat’s going on: \u003c/strong\u003eCovid-19 brutalized urban retail corridors. First, cities emptied out when companies started working from home. At the same time, people started shopping online by the cartload (which puts more demand on warehouses, not actual store locations). Finally, the tourists so many of these luxury retailers depend on were forced to take staycations.  \u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAn extreme example: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSwiss retailer Akris just bought three properties along Madison Ave. at about \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003e80% below \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003epeak sales prices in 2014 ($1,340/square foot average vs. $7,589), \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/madison-avenues-prime-retail-properties-sell-for-decade-low-price-11602586801?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrites the WSJ\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eNow for an M. Night Shyamalan twist\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThey might appear in the dumps, but commercial rents are still \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/11/opinion/nyc-commercial-rent-reform.html?referringSource=articleShare\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003etoo \u003c/em\u003ehigh\u003c/a\u003e right now, and that’s crippling NYC and other cities’ abilities to rebound economically, argues Columbia University law professor Tim Wu in a NYT op-ed. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWu writes that rents don’t reflect current market conditions. Landlords are incentivized to keep rents artificially high for a few reasons, including... \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSome landlords can afford to be patient and hold out for when demand returns.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOther landlords simply can’t lower rents based on agreements with lenders.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eLower rents can lead to depressed property values, the last thing a landlord wants.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eInflated rents are bad for the economy because when businesses can’t afford to set up shop, high vacancy rates can suck the vitality out of a neighborhood. In Times Square in Q3, 29% of space was available. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eWu proposes a few fixes, such as establishing minimum-rent terms and tweaking zoning laws, and says cities can use this crisis as an opportunity to come back better than ever.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003ePaystack\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYou’ll never guess: Stripe. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, payments processor Stripe announced \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/10/15/stripe-acquires-nigerias-paystack-for-200m-to-expand-into-the-african-continent/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eit’s acquiring\u003c/a\u003e Nigerian fintech Paystack for a rumored $200+ million—a record-setting deal for both Stripe and Nigeria. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSimilar to its new parent, Paystack offers software that facilitates digital transactions for 60,000+ business customers. TechCrunch previously dubbed it “the Stripe of Africa,” and Stripe led an $8 million round in Paystack in 2018.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong data-stringify-type=\"bold\" style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe similarities continue: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePaystack was a 2016 grad of Silicon Valley’s esteemed Y Combinator accelerator, as was Stripe in 2010.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eStripe’s been looking abroad for a while \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn April, the company raised $600 million at a $36 billion valuation to help fund international expansion. In the last 18 months, it’s moved into 17 new countries. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Paystack acquisition shows Stripe is betting on emerging African markets, where e-commerce is growing faster than the global average. And among them, Nigeria is the strongest magnet for tech: Last year, Nigerian fintechs received a quarter of all VC funding that went to African startups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS Norm\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA National Student Clearinghouse report surveyed institutions representing 9.2 million students just to come to the same conclusion one could arrive at by scrolling through TikTok—\u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/michaeltnietzel/2020/10/15/college-enrollment-update-undergraduate-numbers-now-down-4-nationwide/#1ddd0eb6389d?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eway fewer\u003c/a\u003e high-school grads enrolled in college this year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Clearinghouse \u003ca href=\"https://nscresearchcenter.org/stay-informed/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e found that overall undergraduate populations shrank by 4%, with over two-thirds of the decline coming from first-time college students. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBreaking it down: \u003c/strong\u003eThe biggest drop-off comes from community college enrollment, where freshman numbers are down 22.7%. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThat decline is surprising when you consider community college enrollment \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/college-enrollment-slid-this-fall-with-first-year-populations-down-16-11602734726?mod=hp_featst_pos3\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eoften jumps\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e during a recession, as adults go back to school to acquire new skills and families look to save on tuition.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOne type of college weathering the storm?\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e \u003c/strong\u003ePrivate, for-profit, four-year institutions. Enrollment is actually up 3.7% compared to the previous fall. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e With hopes of a V-shaped recovery fading, and family finances still under pressure, the ripple effects from the pandemic are rippling. “I fear that many of those students will never get back,” said Doug Shapiro, executive director of the National Student Clearinghouse.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F10%2F15%2Fcollege-enrollment-especially-firstyear-students-continues-fall\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-stocks-cannabis-focus/cannabis-companies-betting-on-a-biden-win-ready-ipos-idUSKBN2702IO?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eU.S. weed companies\u003c/a\u003e are banking on a Biden/Harris W. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eA joint effort: \u003c/strong\u003eSen. Kamala Harris, Biden’s VP pick, said during last week’s debate that the Biden administration would \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-cannabis-stocks/weed-stocks-surge-as-kamala-harris-vows-to-decriminalize-pot-in-debate-idUSKBN26T3IH?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epush for decriminalization\u003c/a\u003e at the federal level if they win in November.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnd if the Senate also flips from red to blue, it will likely be more impactful for marijuana policy than whoever is sitting in the Oval Office. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRepublican Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has repeatedly struck down legislation that would allow financial institutions more freedom to work with cannabis companies. If the Senate adopts a more chill stance on weed, it would pave the way for U.S.-based companies to \u003ca href=\"https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/10/14/this-marijuana-stock-might-just-be-the-biggest-win/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elist their shares\u003c/a\u003e on major stock exchanges.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eAugust cannabis sales were up 26% in California and 34% in Nevada compared to last year, according to BDS Analytics.
